properties.chapter: Bodleian Library MS. Ouseley Add. 176 fol. 311b
properties.description: This image is from the Great Book of Kings called ‘The Shahnama’ written by Firdawsi in the 11th century. It contains national epic stories of the Rulers and Kings of Greater Iran. Written in Persian, ithas been translated multiple times into different languages. This exemplary poem is regarded in a manner that The Shahnama’s stature is compared to the Great Indian Mythological epic ‘Mahabharata’. "This book is an ideal expression of royal authority, legitimacy, and epic royal duty. Amongst numerous tales of other Kings and Rulers, One such legendary story was the Story of Iskandar, popularly known as Alexander the Great. This image depicts Iskandar and the Talking Tree which is one of the finest and greatest legends from the Shahnama. It depicts Iskandar’s arrival at one of the worldly wonders from his journey, where he walks into a land of speaking tree with male and female heads. The wise tree, shown here has both human and animal heads, which forecasts the death of the king in a strange land, away from his kingdom and family." (National Museum of Asian Art 2020))

properties.source-credit: Image of Iskandar, famously known as Alexander the Great
properties.description: Iskandar, son of Son of Dáráb from his wife, Nahid who was the daughter of Failakús reaching the land of the Speaking tree. When Dáráb and Nahid were pregnant with Sikandar, Dáráb was no longer in love with her and she was sent back to her father. Failakús, to save his daughter's reputation tells everyone that Sikandar was his son. Later on, Dáráb marries another woman and gives birth to another son Dárá. When Sikandar and Dárá grew and took the heir to their respective kingdoms, Dárá gets Murdered and leaves his kingdom to Sikandar, his stepbrother. After taking the reign of Iran, Sikandar in order to gain power, knowledge and wisdom plans to visit the Western Sea and the Wonders of the world.In his travels, he confronts different enemies and learns from various cultures. He meets Ruler of India-son of Qaydafa, Queen of Andalus, He visites the land of Brahmans, The great mountains of  Gog and Magogs and lastly at the end of the world he comes across a mystical tree which has two trunks together, male and female. The tree warns Iskandar of his acts and asks him to leave his throne which will cause his death but he foregoes the warning and dies in Babylon away from his family. (Davis 2016,668-669

properties.chapter: Chapter 3: the tale of the talking tree
properties.description: Talking tree is one of the sacred trees and have mythological meaning behind it. It has roots from Western nations like China, India and some parts of Europe aswell. One such mythical tale of this giant tree is from Indo-Persian lore known as “Waqwaq” tree whose fruits are in shape of men and female and animal head. In another persian story this tree is called “Wak Wak” which has an ability to speak. An alternate story says that the heads are hung from the tree and when detached it is silenced and dead. But in Firdawsi’s version, The tree doesn’t have a specific name. The tree trunk is composed of both man and woman, and its fruits have heads of various animals and human that can predict the future.One side of the trunk which is female, smells sweet like musk and speaks during night time and during the day the male side speaks. In the Shahnama, The talking tree both from female and male side warns Iskandar about the pride of his throne and greed. After repeated warnings day and night, the tree prophesied his death and exact details about it. (Soltani and Saadatmand 2017,71-72)

properties.chapter: Chapter 4: conversation between tree and Sikandar
properties.description: One of the epic poems of Shahnama is when Iskandar lands himself in the territory of Speaking Tree. Upon arrival, iskandar and his troop heard human voices which were coming from a tree leaves. They hear loud male voice saying, "However much Sekandar wanders in the world, he has already seen his share of blessings: when he has reigned for fourteen years, he must quit the royal throne." Listening to this heartbreak words coming from tree, he retires in sadness and sleeps. Until the midnight, there was silence along with grief and suddenly the other trunk of the tree, the female side speaks "Do not puff yourself up with greed; why torment your soul in this way? Greed makes you wander the wide world, harass mankind, and kill kings. But you are not long for this earth now; do not darken and deaden your days like this." Hearing his fate, Iskandar lastly asks the tree, "Will this fateful day come in Greece; will my mother see me alive again, before someone covers my face in death?" Then the speaking tree replies "Few days remain; You must prepare your final baggage train. Neither your mother, nor your family,Nor the veiled women of your land will see Your face again. Death will come soon: you’ll die In a strange land, with strangers standing by. The stars and crown and throne and worldly glory Are sated with Sekandar and his story." (Davis 2016,668-669) This conversation hit Sekandar like a sword in his heart. He then collected gifts from the town’s nobility and leaves the town with heavy heart. Soon in another city, he dies.

The image from this folio doesn’t portray the segregated two trunks but the manuscript differs in the writing. According to the North Indian version of Shahnama in British Library, it is drawn as it is written. In the comparative picture, we see the left side of the tree with female heads and limbs. The female trunk speaks and smells like a sweet musk and speaks only at night. At midnight when Iskandar is resting under the tree, the female trunk is the one which foretells his fate and his death. She says, “Few days remain;You must prepare your final baggage train. Neither your mother, nor your family,Nor the veiled women of your land will see Your face again. Death will come soon: you’ll die In a strange land, with strangers standing by. The stars and crown and throne and worldly glory Are sated with Sekandar and his story.” (Davis 2016,668-669)

Like in Chinese culture, every thing has two energies, the Yin and Yang. It holds a great significance in their culture and in that spectrum, they call the femine side- Yin and the masculine side - Yang (Solomon 2010) Similarly, The speaking tree has two sides- the male and female. The text depicts the right side of the speaking tree with male heads and limbs. The male trunk speaks during the day and in their tormented foreboding voice they warn Iskandar about his pride and greed of the throne. The male tree tells iskandar that he has seen his share of blessings and its time to quit his throne.  (Davis 2016,668-669)
